awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structures, Mechanism, and Functional Relevance of Filament Formation by Non-Cytoskeletal Enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will increase the understanding of a newly discovered mechanism of controlling enzyme activity, which involves the formation of linear self-assemblies (i.e. filaments). In particular, the reason for this behavior, and those situations where such behavior is advantageous, will be uncovered. Such understanding will aid in the understanding of enzyme function in normal biology, but also in many different diseases as well. The behavior can also be harnessed for new applications such as in biotechnology, material science, and the creation of new diagnostic tools. Broader impacts to society include opportunities for training of students at the high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels in scientific approaches and methods. Outreach and recruiting efforts will be made to broaden opportunities for training to include members from communities under-represented in science.  
     
The overall scientific goal of this project is to discover the purposes and advantages of regulation of enzyme activity via homogeneous, linear polymerization (or filamentation). Specifically, the hypotheses that this mechanism is superior in rapid activation, and in controlling substrate specificity to secondary substrates under only particular reaction conditions, will be tested using the SgrAI enzyme system. In addition, hypotheses derived from structural studies will be tested, namely in how filamentation activates the enzyme for DNA cleavage, and how DNA sequences of the two types of substrates control enzyme activity by controlling filamentation. Finally, the research will be broadened to include a second filament forming enzyme, phosphofructokinase-1, to develop a full kinetic model so that key advantages of filamentation to this enzyme's regulation may be identified. Methodologies to be used include global kinetic modeling of enzyme activity data derived from single turnover reactions and detected via changes in FRET signals or conversion of radiolabeled substrates to products. Structural studies will utilize state-of-the-art cryo-electron microscopy and x-ray crystallographic methods. Mutagenesis will be used to create variants of the enzymes to test specific hypotheses, and DNA cleavage or fructose phosphorylation assays used to measure reactivity and substrate specificity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Filament formation by metabolic, biosynthetic, and other enzymes has recently come into focus as a mechanism to fine-tune enzyme activity in the cell. Filamentation is key to the function of SgrAI, which is a sequence-specific DNA endonuclease that has served as a model system to provide some of the best insights into the biophysical characteristics of filamentation and its functional consequences. Prior structural and biochemical work has revealed that filamentation stabilizes SgrAI DNA-bound protein dimers in an activated enzyme conformation, which leads to accelerated DNA cleavage activity and expanded DNA sequence specificity. However, the mechanistic bases underlying DNA cleavage acceleration and sequence specificity expansion has remained unclear. Using structural biology and biochemistry, the work here served to directly address this limitation and shed mechanistic light on SgrAI-mediated catalytic function. Using high-resolution cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM), we determined multiple cryo-EM structures of filamentous SgrAI when the protein was bound to intact primary site DNA and trapped under different circumstances prior to the DNA cleavage reaction. We also determined a structure of filamentous SgrAI containing cleaved substrate DNA. The atomic models arising from the cryo-EM data revealed the enzymatic configuration immediately prior to and following the enzymatic cleavage reaction, respectively, and explained how, upon filamentation, conformational changes in the enzyme contribute to accelerated enzyme catalysis. Furthermore, through a novel X-ray structure of SgrAI in its apo state, we discovered how a key component of the protein undergoes a disorder-to-order transition upon DNA recognition. The apo structure explains how filamentation, rather than DNA binding, allosterically regulates enzyme sequence specificity. Biochemical kinetic modeling of the DNA cleavage pathway complemented the structural biology findings to reveal a slow, rate-limiting, second-order association rate constant for filament assembly. We provide multiple sources of evidence to support the general idea that the filamentation mechanism is superior to non-filamenting mechanisms to ensure rapid activation and sequestration of SgrAI’s DNA cleavage activity on phage DNA and away from the host chromatin, thereby safeguarding the bacterial host. Collectively, these data have advanced our understanding of how filamentation can regulate enzyme structure and function, while the experimental strategies used for SgrAI can be more generally applied to other enzymatic systems to identify novel functional roles for filamentation. Broader impact components of the grant included outreach efforts to a local high school as well as training experiences for undergraduate researchers. These efforts served to engage youth during early stages of their scientific development and promote a general interest in future STEM careers.
